#Text=CHAPTER XXIV
#Text=FROM the rescue of Lord Southery my story bears me mercilessly on to other things .
#Text=I may not tarry , as more leisurely penmen , to round my incidents ; they were not of my choosing .
#Text=I may not pause to make you better acquainted with the figure of my drama ; its scheme is none of mine .
#Text=Often enough , in those days , I found a fitness in the lines of Omar :
#Text=We are no other than a moving show Of Magic Shadow-shapes that come and go Round with the Sun-illumined Lantern held In Midnight by the Master of the Show .
#Text=But " the Master of the Show , " in this case , was Dr. Fu-Manchu !
#Text=I have been asked many times since the days with which these records deal : Who WAS Dr. Fu-Manchu ?
#Text=Let me confess here that my final answer must be postponed .
#Text=I can only indicate , at this place , the trend of my reasoning , and leave my reader to form whatever conclusion he pleases .
#Text=What group can we isolate and label as responsible for the overthrow of the Manchus ?
#Text=The casual student of modern Chinese history will reply : " Young China . " This is unsatisfactory .
#Text=What do we mean by Young China ?

#Text=In my own hearing Fu-Manchu had disclaimed , with scorn , association with the whole of that movement ; and assuming that the name were not an assumed one , he clearly can have been no anti-Manchu , no Republican .
#Text=The Chinese Republican is of the mandarin class , but of a new generation which veneers its Confucianism with Western polish .
#Text=These youthful and unbalanced reformers , in conjunction with older but no less ill-balanced provincial politicians , may be said to represent Young China .
#Text=Amid such turmoils as this we invariably look for , and invariably find , a Third Party .
#Text=In my opinion , Dr. Fu-Manchu was one of the leaders of such a party .
#Text=Another question often put to me was : Where did the Doctor hide during the time that he pursued his operations in London ?
#Text=This is more susceptible of explanation .

#Text=For a time Nayland Smith supposed , as I did myself , that the opium den adjacent to the old Ratcliff Highway was the Chinaman 's base of operations ; later we came to believe that the mansion near Windsor was his hiding-place , and later still , the hulk lying off the downstream flats .
#Text=But I think I can state with confidence that the spot which he had chosen for his home was neither of these , but the East End riverside building which I was the first to enter .

#Text=Of this I am all but sure ; for the reason that it not only was the home of Fu-Manchu , of Karamaneh , and of her brother , Aziz , but the home of something else -- of something which I shall speak of later .
#Text=The dreadful tragedy ( or series of tragedies ) which attended the raid upon the place will always mark in my memory the supreme horror of a horrible case .
#Text=Let me endeavor to explain what occurred .
#Text=By the aid of Karamaneh , you have seen how we had located the whilom warehouse , which , from the exterior , was so drab and dreary , but which within was a place of wondrous luxury .

#Text=At the moment selected by our beautiful accomplice , Inspector Weymouth and a body of detectives entirely surrounded it ; a river police launch lay off the wharf which opened from it on the river-side ; and this upon a singularly black night , than which a better could not have been chosen .
#Text=" You will fulfill your promise to me ?

#Text= Aziz lies in the private room , " she explained eagerly , her old accent more noticeable than usual .

_	_	_	_

#Text= We have nothing to fear from him .

_	_	_	_

#Text= I think perhaps I 'd better come in , too , " said Weymouth slowly .

column1: #Text=Karamaneh shrugged her shoulders with quick impatience , and unlocked the door in the high brick wall which divided the gloomy , evil-smelling court from the luxurious apartments of Dr. Fu-Manchu .
#Text=" Make no noise , " she warned .
#Text=And Smith and myself followed her along the uncarpeted passage beyond .
#Text=Inspector Weymouth , with a final word of instruction to his second in command , brought up the rear .
#Text=The door was reclosed ; a few paces farther on a second was unlocked .
#Text=Passing through a small room , unfurnished , a farther passage led us to a balcony .
#Text=The transition was startling .
